questions.question_text: Where is an IP packet routed if the packet does not match any routes in the routing table?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct, but it depends if the default gateway is configured, else drop traffic.
D is the single option decent

Selected Answer: D
Default gateway is the only answer that makes sense, but actually if a packet destination is not included in the routing table then it is discarded

comments.content: ip default-gateway would technically fit this question as it doesn't show up in a device without a routing table (l2 switch). Agreed.. stupid wording.

discussion.content: This question does not have any right answer. Maybe could be a misleading with default route, but if a default route is defined it was present in routing table. So the right answer should be "The packet is discarded".
I had this question also on my exam last week. None are correct: there are 3 DNS query types: recursive, iterative, and non-recursive. PTR, A, AAAA are DNS records not query types.

Selected Answer: BC
PTR and AAAA
https://easydmarc.com/blog/top-8-most-common-types-of-dns-records/

ACK and DISCOVER seem DHCP, Inverse seems resolution.
The best options are BC

Selected Answer: BC
B & C are correct despite the poor wording. I chose these on my exam and got 100% on the "Network Fundamentals" portion.

B & C are correct 
IBM names these "records" as queries as well:
https://www.ibm.com/docs/es/itcam-transactions/7.4.0.1?topic=monitor-dns-query-types
As Daeh mentionned, B & C are the correct answers. D & E would apply to DHCP, not DNS.

comments.content:
Wrong. B & C is correct. The query itself, identified by its type. There are lots of types of DNS queries. Here are the main ones:
Type “A” for IPv4 addresses
Type “AAAA” for IPv6 addresses
Type “CNAME” (Canonical Names) – specifies a domain name that has to be queried in order to resolve the original DNS query
Type “PTR” (Pointer) that specified a reverse query (requesting the FQDN – Fully Qualified Domain Name – corresponding to the IP address you provided)
Type “NS” (Name Server) to get information about the authoritative name server
Type “SOA” (Start Of zone Authority): used when transferring zones
Type “MX” (Mail eXchange) to request information about the mail exchange server for a specific DNS domain name https://accedian.com/blog/dns-query-main-types/
These are not query types. These are DNS records.

discussion.content: It's D & E

questions.question_text: Which two query types does a client make to a DNS server? (Choose two.)
What are two functions of a routing table on a network device? (Choose two.)

choices.A: It lists the routes to drop traffic.
choices.E: It lists entries more than two hops away.
choices.B: It lists the routes to a particular destination.
choices.D: It lists hosts that are one hop away.
choices.C: It lists the static and dynamic entries.

discussion.content: B and C is correct

Selected Answer: BC
Obious B and C

comments.content:
C is also correct, RT list sources or entries of route marked with codes such as O, R , C, L.

B and C are correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Poor writing on the answers.
Only B I know is correct
It should be B since Load Balancers main function is to distribute traffic across multiple servers.

Selected Answer: B
B makes more sense but the redaction is terrible

choices.C: traffic in the network by leveraging the switch architecture
choices.A: different TCP connections to the routers

questions.question_text: What does a load balancer distribute in a network environment?

discussion.content: The question says "limits", for me that is the function of the L2 Switch, it separates traffic in different broadcast domains, whereas a router "forwards" traffic based on the routing table and the routing protocol. The answer for me is D - Device E Layer 2

Since servers are in different networks, they need a router to communicate. The router does not send the packets to the firewall because the next hop is on the same interface that connects down to the servers.
It cannot be device D. Both servers are on the SAME subnet, therefore Packets will NOT traverse the router. So the answer has to be D (switch). This could be done via VACLs, PVLANs, etc.

Selected Answer: C
Answer C

The answer is C - Device D
The question says "which device limits data BETWEEN the servers". Aka Server 1 is sending data to server 2, which device limits/blocks data between the two separate subnets? the Router!

Selected Answer: C
The router is needed in order to let them communicate since they are on different subnets.

Selected Answer: C
Device D

Selected Answer: D
D: The switch is the device that splits the network into multiple VLANs, thus limiting the communication
The router will route between the VLANs and enable traffic

It allows the traffic, but limits it.
Switch not doing any layer 3 function or trunking.
Answer should be Device D router --> as it allows the traffic but limits it by not allowing broadcast network type

Selected Answer: D
Switch E.

Selected Answer: D
Switch(device E) 'limits' the traffic between server1 and server2. Router enables this traffic!

comments.content: this question appears in my exam, but with another sentence, up what device can comunicate the hosts? My answer was device switch

discussion.content:
Network with VLAN
When VLANs are implemented on a switch, the transmission of unicast, multicast, and broadcast traffic from a host in a particular VLAN, are limited to the devices present in the VLAN.
So, i think is D. Device E , but the question is weird and freaky

stupid question, because the firewall, router, and switch could be enabled with QoS to limit traffic to a destination device via layer-2 (switch) or layer-3 (router/firewall). Policy based routing could be configured on the router and is that a layer-3 switch?

Selected Answer: C
The packets will not go through the firewall.
They would go to the router and it will decide what to do

The switch is just an L2 switch, it is not a multilayer switch. In order for the logical networks to communicate with each other a router is required. Again it is because they are in different logical broadcast domain and we require an L3 device to route traffic between domains. Multilayer L2/L3 switch is fine, but the one provided just L2 hence unable to route traffic between broadcast domains.

You could configure the firewall to limit traffic over a threshold, and you could configure QoS on the routers to limit traffic, and if that's a L3 switch, using QoS you could limit traffic from the source to the destination too. The question is bogus
Silly question.. it can also be B(the firewall) if both of the router's interface was configured as a trunk port.
It should be D

comments.content:
It allows the traffic, but limits it.
Switch not doing any layer 3 function or trunking.
Answer should be Device D router --> as it allows the traffic but limits it by not allowing broadcast network type
Question says "Which Device limits traffic", the switch separates the traffic in 2 broadcast domains mean VLANs at firts. The router interconect such as broadcast domains .

this 100%, its trying to trick you by putting 2 servers in different subnets right next to each other, they have to contact a layer 3 device first to talk to each other. always assume router unless told otherwise.
Answer should be C. Server 1 and Server 2 are on different subnet and that means they have different broadcast domains and it limits traffic type like broadcast traffic.
